reviewText:
One of the best hidden object games I've played so far, if you can forgive it's weaknesses that come from it's genre. Some story elements and puzzles makes absolutely no sense (Part of your clock ending up I think in a police officer's safe??), and the way characters move is a little rigid - though the developers took their time to animate whole body-scale moving of lots of (!) characters, this is quite a minor flaw.

Strong aspects of the game:
There is a story with lots of small details in it and lots ( and I do mean lots) of dialogue with actually quite deep characters.
Really nice, albeit short soundtracks which are pleasant to listen to even after half an hour.
Some puzzles are extraordinary. Lots of the puzzles' design is original, but there are some in the bonus chapter that actually challenging, and I'm really happy about it.
Nice graphics and quality hidden object scenes
Really intresting Interview with the Developers in Extras :) Check it out! (Sadly only with subtitles)
And lastly: a game that is a little darker than the usual. Sorry, but I'm a little fed up with HOGs where there is such a happy ending that even the murderous ghosts end up happy and content. (Khm, Nightmares from the Deep 1,3) I wanted a game similar to The Dorian Gray Syndrome, and this really brings the same atmosphere :)Weak aspects of the game:
Relatively low number of Hidden Object Scenes, if you're liking them, you'll definitely feel this as a negative.
Strange logic of item placement, even compared to other hidden object games - it's especially easy to notice as the story heavily leans on logic.
A little short? I've ~ 10 hours in the game (at least 1 hour afk) and this is 2 full gameplay without skipping dialoguesPricewise: I've got this game in a 3-game bundle for 2$ maybe, for that price it was really worth it.  I would say it's a good purchase if you can get it for 1-5 $/€ - the lower, the better  for you :)

reviewText: I'm getting tired of this crap. How am I supposed to enjoy the story if the gameplay doesn't make any sense. Everything is just so random... I mean, there is a secret compartment in someone's house containing a puzzle piece that fits in a puzzle in MY house and when I open it I'll find a door handle or something, because that was worth hiding, right? Why the hell is a cuckoo from my grandfather clock hidden on the police station?\nYou're supposed to be an investigator but everything is so devoid of logic that there is no investigating" at all
date: you're just running around collecting random stuff (mostly keys
recommended: handles and puzzle pieces). Also because everything is scattered without any logic you either have to write down the location of every puzzle or you have to rely on the hint system constantly.\nThe thing is I KNOW that it's possible to make a game in this genre that makes at least some sense
hoursPlayed: you just have to put some effort in it.\n\nThe graphics and animations are fine
voteText: but the story is really stupid and the characters are either annoying or boring. There is a cutscene where some character starts to explain
votesHelpful: everything and it takes like 10 minutes... it's so boring that even the main hero falls asleep!"

reviewText: This second installment in the Brink of Consciousness series serves as both a stand-alone Victorian detective story with a slight touch of occult, and a vague prologue for Oscar's tale in Dorian Gray Syndrome, for the perceptive gamer. I most certainly liked it. The terror factor is lighter compared to the first game, yet the elegance of Victorian Gothic is present and well grasped. It serves as an adventure game rather than a HOG however, which makes the game memorable compared to others of the genre. If you've played the first game, this prequel is meaningful. I advice the tone, and the experience.

reviewText: Excellent story, and despite the other review, good gameplay.\n\nIt's not too long (4-6 hours, so I'd recommend getting it on sale), but if you enjoy point and click, hidden objects, and puzzles, you'll like this.
voteText: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Rather short (4 hours) and... Deadly. It lacks everything. HOGs are rarely logical but this one wins the absurdity trophy: the story is totaly silly, clues are hidden in everybody's homes and the characters rarely make any sens and constantly act stupid. The graphics are very dark and dull; and when they're not dark they lack contrast. So it's hard to distinguish anything and it makes everything ugly.  It also makes the HOG scenes a torture. The general darkness do get a bit better in the second half of the game but comes back in the bonus chapter.

The animations are horrible, the characters are stiff as wood logs and glide everywhere.The voice overs are quite good but the story and the characters are so silly and boring that you'll fall asleep; there's far too much dialogue. Yes, I did fell asleep during the ending dialogue that lasts 5 long minutes! The music is re used from the Women's Murder Club games (those are good, get them) and clearly doesn't fit this setting and only enhances the general dullness. The mini-games are fine but easy.

I didn't like it at all, it's boring and dull. There's plenty of better HOGs out there, so I cannot recommend this game, even on sale, and even though it's a good cure for insomnia.
Avoid at all cost.
voteText: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Short version: 85%The Lonely Hearts Murders has one of the best stories in hidden object game history, along with great and many dialogues and a good number of original puzzles. Just don’t expect much logic in level progression, because there is none.

Long version:The Lonely Hearts Murders is sort of a prequel to Dorian Gray Syndrome, set in London around the turn of the 20th century. It is more of a classic detective story than a psychological thriller. You play as a middle-aged father who, with the help of the police, is trying to save his daughter from the clutches of a serial murderer who “helps” heartbroken young people by killing them.
It isn’t really original, but which murder mystery really is? What is important that excellent actors play well-written characters, and there is more dialogue than in any other hidden object game ever made.

If not for the gameplay, this one could have been a perfect one. But unlike Dorian Gray Syndrome, the progression here isn’t really logical, quite the opposite. Items are always found in the most ridiculous and illogical places, and there are barely enough scenes to really classify it as a hidden object title.
Still… if you want a great story for a casual game, get it. I cannot express in words how much it will be worth it.

reviewText: Not as good as the first one, but still quite enjoyable. I got it on sale so it was worth the money but I'm not sure if I'd pay full price for it. I think it would be more appropriate priced in the 5 dollar range.

reviewText:
I played the first game of this series.  Dorian Grey and it was a solid game. This one even looks better. The resolution is better as it now fills most of my screen. The older game I had to play with black bars all around the screen. The hint system has now been improved and tells you where to go instead of having to look at the guide.

The game looks great and the voices are very well done. A very good game so far.

The same group also made a game called Nearwood its another HOG game. I very much liked that game as well. Out of all of those games I enjoyed this one the most. The graphics and story are just a lot more involved and in depth. I really enjoyed listening to the developers explain some of the story lines in the game. Also the puzzles for the most part were a lot better done in this game then the other 2 in the series. If your a fan of HOG then you should love this game. Its spooky and the graphics and sound just pop with flair. A great game.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game has a vastly different feel than your typcial Aritfax Mundi game. It has a dark feel to it, that never really lets up. For the most part the HOGs are not clever just well hidden. No tricks but nothing slick either. I hate it when an HOG hides 3/4 of the object and then your have to guess at it. The Brink games  are not like that at all. And minimal language complications although watch out for the trumpet really being a french horn (so common in HOGs). I would rate this game a tad lower than the Dorian Grey game. However, where Dorian gets a 10 this game gets an 8.5. The story and atomspher are top notch for an HOG, The acting is passable but falls way short of the first game. I think for me the thing that makes Lonely Hearts a good game and not a great game is that there is too much going back and forth to the scenes and it almost . . . almost got to be tedius. Still, I like this game and look forward to any more games in the Brink of Consciousness series.
Great hidden object game with an interesting plot

A very good game, great to see a mix of hidden object and adventure style game play together in this game.  There is a lot to do in this game and many of the puzzles are really good.  Most of the puzzles are quite obvious with no real place where you are likely to get totally stuck because someone decided that you need to use two most random items together as happens in many other adventure games and even if you get really stuck if your in easy mode there is always the guide and hint system to help you along.

reviewText: This game has a good story. Even playing the very short time I did I could tell the story line was interesting. With that said, I am not a fan of the gameplay. I know hidden object games have plenty of puzzles and such to find the things you need but it didn't make any sense. The beginning puzzles, it made no sense for there to be puzzles at that time.\n\nI like hidden object games but this one just adds puzzles in places of the story that make no sense to being there. For example, why do you need keys to invite a friend into your own house?!!?! Makes no sense.

reviewText: The story is good. Graphic wise, its okay but it pauses for a few seconds when you try to change areas. As for the puzzles, some of them are really hard to spot and some are too specific. Overall, this game is worth playing.

A nice story-driven casual point-and-click adventure, with several easy mini-games and hidden-object scenes. The story is engaging and very well crafted, with excellent dialog and voice acting. However, note that gameplay is *very* casual, so much so that you might even consider this game to be a visual novel.

This game is unconnected to the first installment in the Brink of Consciousness series, and indeed you can play them in any order. (There's an attempt to connect the two in the bonus chapter of this game, but it doesn't change the fact that you can play them in any order.)

The story is better crafted than the first game, but the puzzles are much easier. Still, they are original and satisfying. Move the ball around, yay. Make all the lights light up, yay.

If you've played such games before, I strongly recommend playing in expert" level to at least give yourself a minimal brain challenge. But really

An excellent casual adventure game with minor puzzles and hidden object games.  Above par voice acting compared to what is typical for the genre.  The story is a genuine detective mystery, and while the story is interesting, the placement of the clues and puzzles does not mesh with the story.  This could have easily rectified, but overall this is a great game, although it clocks barely at 3 hours gameplay time with the bonus chapter.  Also, although the is the second installment in the Brink of Consciousness series, based on the storylines it actually meshes better if you play this one before the Dorian Gray Syndrome game (first in the series).  The bonus chapter in this one has a bit of tie-in with the main story of the first game.

Hilariously bad but I still couldn't put it down - glad it's over and bonus chapter provided a bit of a twist... the Dorian Gray game is better but this was so bad it provided a few hours of smirks and laughs. 10/10 for that alone :-D

In the last several years, I have played A LOT of HOS-based adventures. And I can be very forgiving about things - too many HOS and not enough puzzles (or vice versa), puzzles which are so easy they're boring or so hard they inspire rage-quitting, lame live-action actors or bad voice acting, even graphics which are pedestrian. But this is far and away the most frustrating and irritating HOS adventure I've ever played. There are just WAY too many cut scenes, and those cut scenes go on FOREVER. At one point I got up when a cut scene had started, and spent a few minutes getting my nephew a cup of juice, only to find that when I saw back down the scene was still going. And it KEPT going, for at least another five minutes.

And the ending of both the main and the bonus chapters, is entirely cut scene, with no significant player involvement at all. I wouldn't be surprised if there genuinely more cut-scene time than playing time in this game (but I didn't do the math, and I damned sure am not replaying to find out. And nothing about the game play itself, the graphics, the characters, or the strange storyline, made up for insanely long over-abundance of cut scenes.

Like I said, I'm a forgiving reviewer most of the time, but this is easily the worst HOS adventure I've ever played, and nothing redeemed it's shortcomings.

Done in 3.5 for main game and bonus chapter.

However, it feels like most of that time was spent listening to dialogue that went on and on and onnnnnn forever. This one is more puzzle than HOG, with more objects just found around and needing to be used elsewhere to get different objects, and less hidden object scenes. The story is ok, the graphics are great, but the length of uninteresting dialogue, even with OK VO, dragged the whole thing down a notch.

Not *bad* at all, but slightly preferred the first Brink of Consciousness" title from the same dev. Wait for a sale."

This second chapter of The Brink of Consciousness' series is one of the best HOGs on Steam. My old review of this game was negative since there's not support from the developers to solve the technical problems with Windows 7 (it was difficult to even start the game, no text displayed and other compatibility issues) but it works perfectly on Windows 10 and the game is worth the effort. The jump to cutscenes is fluid, the HO scenes, the locations and backgrounds are all very well detailed and the story is engaging with good voice actors, especially compared to other HOGs with their ridiculous plots and silly voices. There's also a bonus chapter available after finishing the main game.

This is the collector's edition which comes with a bonus episode, concept art, in-game soundtrack, wallpapers and interviews with the developers.

The puzzles" are very easy in the main game but it fits well with the laidback theme that is the Hidden Object genre.

There's more or less no logic to where you will find the parts that unlocks doors et cetera. It goes so far you could even mistake your companion for the killer
date: which actually could have been an interesting twist.\n\nThe 2D artwork are great."

reviewText: Great game. I really enjoyed completing this. The story was fun. The puzzles were great. 10/10 for a point and click puzzle game! I've played alot of them previously but this is by far the best one i've played!

However, note that gameplay is *very* casual, so much so that you might even consider this game to be a visual novel.

Good game. Great graphics and decent voice acting. Lovely soundtrack that matches the mood of the story. Very good hidden Object game.

This is a slightly above thumbs in the middle for me.

I loved Dorian Gray Syndrome, and the fact this game is tied to that makes up for a lot. I like the change of pace. It's a detective story instead of a horror. That's fine. I also enjoyed the story for what it was. It moved forward at a good pace, had several interesting characters, and they bothered to explain most of what was going on.

It was the puzzles that kind of had me disappointed. There was some really random stuff going on. Like why were so many pieces of deeply personal belongings hiddein behind painting in someone else's house? Why does my main character just randomly break into his friend's safe? It also turned into a goose chase where you'd only have one item in your inventory. It'd be obvious where you needed to use it, and the result would be another one item that you had to run back across the map in order to use. A fast travel system would have been much appreciated.

That said, I got this on sale for two and a half bucks. It helped me kill a few hours on a lazy night. As far as hidden object games go, it's still better than most of what I've played. Worth a look.

Compared to the Dorian Gray this one falls short. The first game was great in terms of story, art, and progress. The atmosphere is very different w/ the first being more horror. Anyway this serves as prequel giving the player a back story about Oscar’s family. The conclusion to this game is much happier than the first w/ the ominous prediction that there will be more like the villain. The concept of the Brink of Consciosness is definitely intriguing and makes the story memorable unlike many HOG where the events fade before you even finish. If you played the 1st get this one for backstory.
Good HOG game, great graphics and fun puzzles definlitly worth the play for fun of this kind of games.
Loved it!

I love the Hog Genre, but this game just felt too much like a chore for me. The story was alright, but just seemed to drag even though the game is rather short. I agree with how others mentioned that the placement of objects is very random and does not seem to follow any logic. Also There is just too much running around with just an item for my taste.

Visually, the novel is not bad, but I have played ones that I think look much nicer. The voice acting is a nice touch though and I do really like the soundtrack.

I think if you enjoy the plot, this could be a fun game for you.

Overall the game is not bad and fun if you enjoy the genre, but I have certainly played better. I say, if you can get it on sale, go for it.

I just finised this game a few days ago, and it was challenging at times, and seemed like a long game,Jayden was funny leaving details out till last minute. The detective did not do much in the story, and no weapons which was strange, and in this day and age would need the weapons. Some puzzles or objects did not make sense, the characters could of been more devoloped the picture of the girl should be replaced as you only meet her in the end a average  game buy it on special not worth the full price. I have started the bonus chapter which has you as the detective.

Got to the last chapter, there was a bug that caused the games sound to glitch and then somehow scrambled my profile, meaning the game is impossible to launch until i delete the profile completely, and therefore would have to start again. Game breaking bug 0/10.\n\nEDIT: For some reason I was pulled back to complete this game. I experienced another bug, where it would not save at the end (meaning I had to complete the entire extra bonus level in one sitting). There is a fun HOBO game here, albeit with stodgy acting, but the bugs prevent me from being able to recommend it. 5/10

The game is really simple, i prefer bonus part because it introduce you a little the next game about Dorian Gray (not the ♥♥♥♥ing one from fifty ♥♥♥♥ of grey). i'm a little disapointed that there is no sucess but well.
